STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
April 2, 2025
Darnell Thomas Britt
Community Care Organization
18688 Joann St.
Detroit, MI, 48205-2748
Re: License #: CB820315857
Dear Mr. Britt:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
1/30/2025. A preliminary exit conference was held with your agency on 1/30/2025. Due
to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is required.
The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
A six-month provisional license is recommended. If you do not contest the issuance of a
provisional license, you must indicate so in writing on the CWL-4617 Acknowledgement
of appeal rights. If you contest the issuance of a provisional license, you must notify this
office in writing. Even if you contest the issuance of a provisional license, you must still
submit an acceptable corrective action plan.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Rorie Dodge-Pifer at 517-899-6024.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB820315857
Licensee Group Organization: Community Care Organization
Licensee Designee: Kendra Washington
Chief Administrator: Darnell Thomas Britt
Name of Agency: Community Care Organization
Agency Address: 18688 Joann St
Detroit, MI 48205-2748
Agency Telephone #: 313-334-4750
Original Issuance Date: 07/30/2013
Service Types: Supervise Independent Living
1

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12205 Required staff.
(1) An agency shall employ or contract for all the
following staff positions:
(c) Social service worker
At the time of the inspection, the agency did not have any case workers; and had
been without case workers since 11/14/2024. The agency typically has at least two
case workers. The agency's Licensee Designee who normally serves as agency's
supervisor is covering the 19 youth cases the agency has under its supervision.
CPA Rule 400.12205 Required staff.
(8) An agency shall employ or contract for a sufficient
number of competent staff to carry out the provisions
covered by these rules. The workload for each staff
member may not be more than any of the following:
(b) Fifteen children assigned to a social services worker
for purposes of providing direct services in foster care,
independent living, adoption, or post adoption services or
a combination thereof.
The agency is out of compliance with caseload size. The Licensee Designee who is
temporarily serving as the case worker, is carrying 19 independent living youth
cases.
2

CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record must contain all the following
information before employment may occur:
(d) Three references obtained from persons who are
unrelated to the staff person.
Four of six new employee records reviewed did not show compliance:
• Two records showed only two references; and only one of the two references
were dated. I could not determine if that one reference was received before
the respective employees’ 5/12/2024 and 10/29/2024 date of hire.
• A third record showed two undated references; and I could not discern if the
references were received before the employee’s date of hire on 9/17/2024.
• A fourth record showed only two references.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record must contain all the following
information before employment may occur:
(e) A record of any convictions other than minor traffic
violations from either of the following:
(i) The Michigan state police, tribal police, or the
equivalent state or Canadian provincial law enforcement
agency where the person usually resides.
Two of six new employee records reviewed did not show compliance:
• In one record the employee's ICHAT was completed on 11/15/2024, four
days after the employee's 11/21/2024 date of hire.
• The second record showed the employee's ICHAT was completed on
12/3/2024 over a month after the employee's 10/29/2024 date of hire.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record must contain both of the
following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months
after the staff member assumes his or her current
responsibilities. After the initial evaluation, a written
evaluation must be conducted every 12 months.
One of six new employee records reviewed did not show documentation of a
probationary evaluation completed which was due 1/29/2025 per the employee's
10/29/2024 date of hire.
3

Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal November 2023, CAP approved 1/12/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record must contain all the following
information before employment may occur:
(h) Documentation from the department that the person
has not been named in a central registry case as the
perpetrator of child abuse or neglect in Michigan or in
any state where the person lived in the 5 years
preceding hire.
One of six new employee records reviewed showed the employee's central record
clearance was completed on 12/12/2023 which was after the employees 11/8/2023
date of hire.
Violation Established
Renewal Inspection November 2023, CAP approved 1/12/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record must contain all the following
information and documentation, which must be recorded
within 30 calendar days after placement in independent
living and updated at least once every 90 calendar days:
(g) Current documentation of financial support sufficient
to meet the youth's housing, clothing, food, and
miscellaneous expenses.
Four of four open independent living youth records reviewed did not show consistent
quarterly proof of current financial support to meet the youth’s need. The agency
reported it was attempting compliance with this rule by completing a monthly
budget, with the youth, though each record was missing consistent monthly
documentation.
Repeat Violation Established
Renewal Inspection November 2023, CAP approved 1/12/2024.
4

CPA Rule 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record must contain all the following
information and documentation, which must be recorded
within 30 calendar days after placement in independent
living and updated at least once every 90 calendar days:
(o) Service plans as required in R 400.12419 and R
400.12420. If the youth has biological children, the
service plan must address the living arrangement for the
child or children, visitation/parenting time with the youth's
biological children or a clear explanation why this is not
possible or appropriate.
Two of four open independent living youth records reviewed did not show
compliance:
• One record showed the youth's 4/4/2024-7/2/2024 updated service plan
(USP) was completed 2 days late on 7/5/2024. This youth's 7/3/2024-
9/30/2024 USP was completed 36 days late on 11/6/2024. This youth's
10/1/2024-12/26/2024 USP was not signed by a supervisor. Nor was the
youth's 1/6/2024-4/3/2024 and 4/4/2024-7/2/2024 treatment plans uploaded
with the youth's signature. Lastly this youth’s worker's May and June 2024
Independent living placement visits were not listed in the youth's 4/4/2024-
7/2/2024 USP.
• A second record showed the youth's 4/9/2024-7/9/2024 USP was completed
8 days late on 7/16/2024. This youth's 7/8/2024-10/5/2024 USP was
completed 9 days late on 10/15/2024. This youth's 4/9/2024-7/7/2024
treatment plan was not signed by the youth. Lastly this youth’s worker’s
February 2024 independent living placement visit was not listed in the youth's
1/13/2024-4/8/2024 USP.
Repeat Violation Established
Renewal Inspection, November 2023, CAP approved 1/12/2024
Interim Inspection, January 2023, CAP approved 3/22/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living agreement.
(2) The agreement must be signed and dated by the
youth and the social service worker. The agreement
must be reviewed with the youth at least once every 90
calendar days and a copy provided to the youth.
Four of four open independent living youth records reviewed did not show
compliance:
• One record did not show documentation of a quarterly contract due in
November 2024
5

• A second record did not show documentation of a quarterly contract due in
December 2024.
• A third and fourth record did not show consistent documentation of a
quarterly contracts due after the initial contract.
Repeat Violation Established
Renewal Inspection, November 2023, CAP approved 1/12/2024
CPA Rule 400.12511 Termination.
(1) When an agency terminates its independent living
services for a youth, the agency shall document all the
following information in the case record within 30
calendar days of termination of its services:
(c) A summary of the services provided during care and
the needs that remain to be met.
Three of three closed independent youth records reviewed did not show
documentation of a summary of the services provided during care and the needs
that remained to be met. The information was either not documented or left blank
on the action summary form used to document this information.
Repeat Violation Established
Renewal Inspection, November 2023, CAP approved 1/12/2024.
Interim Inspection, January 2023, CAP approved 3/22/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12511 Termination.
(1) When an agency terminates its independent living
services for a youth, the agency shall document all the
following information in the case record within 30
calendar days of termination of its services:
(d) Provision for any follow-up services.
Three of three closed independent youth records reviewed did not show
documentation of provision for any follow-up services. The information was either
not documented or left blank on the action summary form used to document this
information.
Repeat Violation Established
Renewal Inspection, November 2023, CAP approved 1/12/2024
Interim Inspection, January 2023, CAP approved 3/22/2023.
6

CPA Rule 400.12511 Termination.
(2) An agency shall ensure and document that each
youth who ends independent living is provided with all
the following:
(a) Basic information about health, housing, counseling
and mental health services, and emergency resources.
One of three closed independent living youth records reviewed did not show
documentation of basic information about health, housing, counseling and mental
health services, and emergency resources as required by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12511 Termination.
(2) An agency shall ensure and document that each
youth who ends independent living is provided with all
the following:
(b) A birth certificate.
One of three closed independent living youth records reviewed did not contain a
birth certificate as required by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12511 Termination.
(2) An agency shall ensure and document that each
youth who ends independent living is provided with all
the following:
(c) A social security card.
Two of three closed independent living youth records reviewed did contain a social
security card as required by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12511 Termination.
(2) An agency shall ensure and document that each
youth who ends independent living is provided with all
the following:
(d) The youth's funds and personal property.
Two of three closed independent living youth records reviewed did not show
documentation of the youth's funds and personal property as required by the rule.
7

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R400.12507(1) Medical dental and mental health care.
The agency was apprised it shall consistently ensure that the youth’s medical
documents are uploaded to the youth’s official record.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
R400.12212(3)(a) Personnel records.
• The agency reported it regularly has its human resource manager complete
employee performance evaluations; either singularly or by way of input from the
licensee designee, who is the supervisor. The agency acknowledged that its
policy does not indicate this procedure. The agency was advised having its policy
clearly indicate its practice and procedure in this area is advisable, and
evaluations should be based on the supervisor’s assessment of the staff’s
performance.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans during this
licensing period:
The first corrective action plan related to the agency’s 2023 Renewal inspection
where it received 10 rule violations.
During this current Interim inspection, the agency received 15 rule violations. This
was an increase of 5 from the Renewal inspection. Of these 15 citations, 7 are
repeat violations from the Renewal inspection. The agency’s corrective action plan
compliance around these 7 rule violations is as follows: the number of individual
cases cited remained basically the same with respect to 3 rule violations cited;
there was decreases related to 2 other rule violations cited (from 4 of 4 to 3 of 4 for
both); and the number of individual cases cited with respect to the last 2 rule
violations cited increased (from 1 of 4 to 4 of 4 for both).
8

The agency was able to implement some aspect of its corrective action plan such
as the development of a quarterly audit tool, spreadsheet for performance
evaluations and training for staff on independent living discharge documentation. It
was not effective in completion of monthly file audits or the hiring of a new case
worker. And as illustrated by its repeat violations, it was not totally successful with
the corrective action. Also given its current situation around staffing, maintaining
consistent compliance around all areas, could be challenging. They reported they
are trying to hire case workers but are experiencing difficulty.
The second corrective action plan for special investigation 2024SIC00001069
related to a complaint investigation initiated on 1/19/2024. The complaint alleged
the agency refused to work with the child’s parent, failed to ensure the child had
access to food, failed to document independent skills, and to obtain the child’s state
ID. The special investigation did not substantiate those allegations, but the agency
was found in violations of R400.12418(2)(b) for having a late service plan. The
agency submitted an acceptable corrective action that was approved on 3/14/2024.
The corrective action plan indicated the agency would complete a training with staff
around service plans; and it would maintain compliance by way of the supervisor
conducting monthly supervision with workers and completing monthly audits. The
agency completed the stated training and was having regular monthly meeting with
staff. The agency was not successful with completion of monthly case audit. It is
revisiting this action step to look at quarterly case audits once case workers are
hired. It hopes to have a worker in place by the end of March 2025.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency submitted a chief administrator's report dated 10/4/2024, where it
indicated timely documentation continued to be of issue due to a lack of motivated
staff. The chief administrator reported keeping a consistent staffing team is key to
performance improvement and the agency would continue to strive to achieve a
solid team. The chief administrator reported the agency had improved its
completion of service plan reports and the use of checklists and training of the
program manager aided with this improvement. The reported indicated that a
quality team meets to ensure the agency is providing services as required by
policy standards.
The agency must continue to work to hire staff and to ensure it is working to fulfill
the action steps it indicated in its corrective action plan.
Financial Overview
The agency submitted a 2025 annual budget, and the agency’s last annual
independent financial audit for 12/31/2023. A review of the documents did not
reveal any noticeable areas of concern.
Staff Interviews
In addition to discussion with the licensee designee, chief administrator, and
human resource manager at the entrance and exit conference, I interviewed two
9

youth advocates, and the youth advocate supervisor. The staff persons
interviewed all reported staff try to work together to aid the youths in achieving
goals, that the licensee designee and chief administrator both check on the youths
in the program and check on and aid them as well. An area of growth indicated
related to obtaining more support resources for youths, helping new staff to
recognize the difficulties of the job and gaining an appreciation about the fact that
they are dealing with the lives of young people.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through of the agency satellite office at 19992 Kelly Rd. in Harper Woods,
that houses the agency’s administrative office showed renovation occurring by the
building management. The agency reported the building was purchased by new
management, and their lease at the building will end at the end of February. The
agency reported it has obtained a new office space on at 22100 Kelly Rd, in
Harper Woods MI and it will move there soon.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
Not applicable. This is an independent living program.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan modification of the agency’s
license from a regular license to a first provisional license is recommended.
February 14, 2025
________________________________________
Lonia Perry Calloway Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
April 02, 2025
________________________________________
Rorie Dodge-Pifer Date
Area Manager
10
